key_insight: A quantitative evaluation framework reveals that 3D generative models can and do memorize training shapes under many common settings; memorization rises with limited data and high model capacity but is reducible via augmentation and regularization.
problem_solved: Provides the first systematic, measurable way to detect and quantify memorization in 3D shape generators, addressing risks of training-data leakage and lack of generative diversity.
method: Design a memorization evaluation pipeline using 3D-aware similarity metrics (e.g., Chamfer Distance, EMD, IoU) and nearest-neighbor retrieval plus novelty/coverage statistics.
Perform controlled experiments varying dataset size, model capacity/architecture, and training choices (augmentations, regularizers, objectives) to measure their effect on memorization.
Combine quantitative thresholds with qualitative side-by-side comparisons to identify and categorize memorized vs. truly novel generated shapes.
impact: Gives practitioners a practical toolkit to detect and mitigate data leakage in 3D generative pipelines and to tune models for better novelty–fidelity trade-offs, improving safety and generative diversity.
visual_elements: Flowchart of the evaluation framework (input dataset → generator → nearest‑neighbor retrieval → memorization metric computation → decision).
Bar/line charts showing memorization score vs. dataset size and vs. model capacity.
Side‑by‑side visual comparisons of generated shapes and their nearest training neighbors with annotated similarity scores.
Scatterplot or heatmap of fidelity (reconstruction quality) versus novelty (distance to nearest training shape) to illustrate trade-offs.
paper_title: Memorization in 3D Shape Generation: An Empirical Study
paper_authors: Shu Pu, Boya Zeng, Kaichen Zhou, Mengyu Wang, Zhuang Liu
